intro: Angraecum xanthopollinium, commonly known as the yellow-pollinated angraecum, is a rare and striking orchid native to Madagascar. It is characterized by its tall, slender stem and large, showy flowers with a distinctive yellowish hue. The plant produces intricate, spurred flowers that are adapted for pollination by specific moths, showcasing a remarkable example of co-evolution. Its growth habit is epiphytic, meaning it grows on trees without being parasitic, and it thrives in humid, shaded environments. Due to its rarity and unique features, it is highly sought after by orchid enthusiasts and conservationists alike.
